As of now, we will stop displaying the case-ending at the end of the words, however please note that the case-ending does not change the meaning of a word:

القَمَر  =    القمرُ

الشَمس = الشَمسُ

مَلِك =      مَلِكٌ

This word contains the article: ‘el’ which means ‘the’, it then starts with a ‘moon letter‘. If a word starting with a ‘moon letter’ is preceded by the article ‘el’, then the article should be pronounced normally as ‘el’ or ‘l’ followed by the word and forming together one word.
The ‘Taa’ ط is a ‘sun letter’ because it is pronounced using the tongue.
The ‘laam’ ل is a ‘sun letter’, because it is pronounced with the tongue touching the palate. Sun letters are the letters which cannot be pronounced without using the tongue.
The ق at the beginning of this word is a moon letter because it is pronounced from the throat, without using the tongue at all.

Every Arabic letter is either a ‘sun’ or a ‘moon’ letter. A ‘moon’ letter is a letter pronounced from the throat without using the tongue at all. The كـ here is a ‘moon letter’. Pronounce it and note whether you use your tongue or not.

In Arabic there is only one article used for singular, plural, masculine and feminine words: ال , pronounced as ‘el’ or ‘al’. This article is always joined to the word it belongs to, for example: Book= كِتاب , the book = الكِتاب (el-kitaab)

This word is pronounced as ‘bash-shara’. Note that the ‘fat7a’ (‘a’ accent) is written above the ‘shadda’ (the doubler). Here it doubles the ش which means that this letter has to be pronounced extra long, and then followed by an ‘a’ vowel.

Start learning and playing level by level. If you are a beginner you cannot skip any level. Every level contains 2-3 letters. Note that every letter has a name, and a way it is pronounced for example the ‘daal’ is pronounced as ‘d’. The better you play the more lamps you collect. You need at least one lamp per level in order to unlock the next level.

!مَبروك! يا لكَ من بَطل 

Congratulations! You are a champ! You have successfully completed all levels! I have made your wish to learn Arabic come true ;-))

Don’t forget: practice makes perfect! In Arabic: التِكرار يُعلِّم الحِمار  :-))

Salaam! Well done my friend! You have unlocked the next letter in this level. New letters will be available upon completion of 60% of each letter within a level, so keep on playing. Good luck! “bi-Tawfiq”!

Your goal is to learn every letter and then test yourself in order to collect lamps. You need to complete 60% of the games before you can unlock the next letter within a level.
Start by touching the ‘i’ near each letter in order to learn. Touch ‘test’ and start with ‘Read & Learn’. Practice the words you’ve learned by playing the games.
Fill the blank with the right letter by touching that letter. Make sure you select the right form of that letter!
Sort the words in the sentence by dragging them into the right position.
Select the right translation of the main sentence. Green means the selection is correct, red means it is wrong. The wrong entries will keep on reappearing until you get them right.

Play the sound first, listen carefully and select the words in the order in which they are spoken out. You can replay the sound as much as you want before starting your selection.

You selected a word by mistake? Sorry! The entry is considered wrong, but no worries, it will come back later! Try to get it right the next time 😉
Select the right word to fill in the blank in the sentence. Touch the sound button to listen to the complete sentence.

Translate the English word to Arabic: select the letters in the correct order in order to form the right word. Touch the letter you want to select. To deselect, touch it again. Touch the sound button if you do not know the translation and it will be spoken out for you.

Match every sound with the right Arabic word and the corresponding picture. A good match of these 3 categories results in a green colour. In order to select the box of the sound make sure that you touch around and not on the sound button.

Match each Arabic word with its corresponding English translation. The words which are not real words, have to be matched with the right English transcription. Green means the match is right and red means the match is wrong.
The small vertical stroke you see here is called the ‘dagger alif’. It is pronounced like a regular ‘alif’: ‘aa’. It only appears on a handful of words. Most keyboards do not offer the ‘dagger alif’.

This word contains the article: ‘el’ which means ‘the’, it then starts with a ‘moon letter‘. If a word starting with a ‘moon letter’ is preceded by the article ‘el’, then the article should be pronounced normally as ‘el’ or ‘l’ followed by the word and forming together one word.

This word contains the article: ‘el’ which means ‘the’, it then starts with a ‘sun letter‘. If a word starting with a ‘sun letter’ is preceded by the article ‘el’, then the ‘l’ of the article will not be pronounced and the first letter of the word will be doubled. E.g.: the light = النّور is pronounced as ‘ennoor’ and not ‘el-noor’.

Tip: if the first letter of a word is a sun letter and it has the article ‘el’ it will also carry a ‘shadda’.

In Arabic there is only one article used for singular, plural, masculine and feminine words: ال , pronounced as ‘el’ or ‘al’. This article is always joined to the word it belongs to, for e.g.: The book = الكِتاب (el-kitaab)”

Sun and Moon letters: every letter in Arabic is either a ‘sun’ or a ‘moon’ letter. A ‘sun’ letter is a letter which when pronounced, the tongue touches the palate or the back of the teeth. The ‘lam’ is a sun letter .The sun letters are: د ذ ر ز ن ت ث ج س ش ص ض ط ظ ل
A ‘moon’ letter is a letter which when pronounced, the tongue is not used at all. The moon letters are: ا و ي ب ح خ ع غ ف ق ك م ه ء
Try to pronounce all of these letters and notice with every letter whether you use your tongue, your throat, or your lips.
This word is pronounced as ‘Tayyib’. Note that the ‘kasra’ (i-accent) is written under the ‘shadda’, and is pronounced as a short ‘i’ after the doubled letter.

The sign you see at the end of this word is called a ‘tanween’. It is pronounced as ‘in’. This sign is a case-ending indicating that the word is indefinite and that it is in the ‘genitive’ case. This sign is sometimes pronounced as ‘ee’ in spoken Arabic.

This word is pronounced as ‘bash-shara’. Note that the ‘fat7a’ (a-accent) is written above the ‘shadda’ . Here it doubles the ش which should be pronounced longer than normal and it is followed by an ‘a’ vowel: shsha.

The sign you see at the end of this word is called ‘tanween’, it is a ‘double-fat7a’ and is pronounced as ‘an’. This is a case-ending indicating that the word is indefinite, and is in the ‘accusative’ case (which means that it serves as a direct-object or an adverb in the sentence). This sign is generally not pronounced in spoken Arabic.

The sign you see at the end of this word is called ‘tanween’. It is a ‘double-damma’ and is pronounced as ‘un’. This sign is a case-ending indicating that the word is indefinite and is in the ‘nominative’ case (which means that it serves as the subject in the sentence). This sign is not pronounced in spoken Arabic.
The symbol you see at the end of this word is called the ‘shadda‘. It doubles the letter on top of which it is written, which means that this particular letter has to be pronounced extra long.

Touch the star (above, right) to flag the words which you still find difficult and wish to practice more. You can also shuffle the cards (above,right), or swap all cards to practice learning from English to Arabic.
